6/6 A takeaway is: let's not overlook the bored kids. The ones who ask too many questions. They can easily fall through the cracks if we don't pay attention. With some guidance, role models, and positive reinforcement, they too can realize their academic and professional dreams.

5/6 The last teacher who had a profound influence on my as a student was the late Dr. Gunter Bruns, who taught me abstract algebra in the third year of my undergraduate. I got a picture from him of what a mathematician was and could be, & how I could chart a course to become one.

4/6 Another teacher who had a profound influence was a gifted ed specialist teacher in Grade 7, who saw a spark in me when my testing didn't reflect it. Up to that point, I was invisible and even maligned by teachers for my incessant boredom and for asking too many questions.

3/6 Out of the dozens of teachers in my career as a student, there were three that stood out. Three!

One was my Grade 11 English teacher who let me think outside of the box, let our class act out Shakespeare, and encouraged me to write, read more, and love language.

2/6 Mathematics didn't become exciting for me until about the third year of my undergraduate degree. At that point, I gained access to a more modern, abstract view of mathematics, and I drifted away from brute force computations, rote learning, and cookbook-style courses.

5/5 Last, bibliometrics like H-factor don't matter as much in #math unlike in the rest of #STEM. NSERC doesn't use them in math. But VPs, Deans and promotion committees are often outside math and the lack of citations is something they use to diminish the work of mathematicians.

4/5 A good place to start your search for citations is to look for books and survey articles in the area. A mathematician told me they instantly reject a paper if it doesn't include the key surveys on a topic. That is perhaps too harsh, but there is a lesson there.

3/5 Second for students or researchers learning about an area, a small number of citations gives a tiny window to peer through to see what is out there. This is especially relevant for students acclimating to a topic. You would be amazed what you can learn from original sources.

2/5 First it does a disservice to the work of others. While it is easy to miss citations, resources like Mathscinet, Google Scholar and arXiv (the latter 2 non-paywalled) make it simpler to find relevant papers and books by keyword searches. Or, ask a colleague in the area.

1/5 A thread on citations for #math twitter. Please, mathematicians, cite each other more! In other #STEM disciplines, citations tend to be extensive. Math papers often (not always) have a smaller number. That's not good practice for several reasons.
